description:
Bacteroides bouchesdurhonensis is a species of anaerobic, Gram-negative bacteria belonging to the genus Bacteroides. It was first isolated from human fecal samples collected in the Bouches-du-Rh√¥ne region of France.

Bacteroides bouchesdurhonensis is a rod-shaped bacterium that is non-spore-forming and non-motile. It is a strictly anaerobic organism, meaning it requires an oxygen-free environment to grow and thrive. The bacterium is chemoorganotrophic, utilizing organic compounds as its primary source of energy and carbon.

Phylogenetically, Bacteroides bouchesdurhonensis is closely related to other Bacteroides species commonly found in the human gut microbiome, such as Bacteroides fragilis and Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron. It is considered a member of the normal gut flora and plays a role in the breakdown and fermentation of complex carbohydrates and other dietary components.

The genome of Bacteroides bouchesdurhonensis has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential interactions within the gut ecosystem. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological and potential clinical significance of this recently described gut bacterial species.
